column1: Portadown (from Irish  Port an Dúnáin 'landing place of the little fort') is a town in County Armagh
column2: Northern Ireland. The town sits on the River Bann in the north of the county
column3: about 24 mi (39 km) southwest of Belfast. It is in the Armagh City
column4: Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council area and had a population of about 22
column5: 000 at the 2011 Census. For some purposes
column6: Portadown is treated as part of the "Craigavon Urban Area"

column1: Although Portadown can trace its origins to the early 17th century Plantation of Ulster
column2: it was not until the Victorian era and the arrival of the railway that it became a major town. It earned the nickname "hub of the North" due to it being a major railway junction; where the Great Northern Railway's line diverged for Belfast
column3: Dublin
column4: Armagh and Derry. In the 19th and 20th centuries Portadown was also a major centre for the production of textiles (mainly linen).

column1: Portadown is the site of the long-running Drumcree dispute
column2: over yearly Orange marches through the mainly Catholic part of town
column3: which has often led to violence. In the 1990s
column4: the dispute intensified and drew worldwide attention to Portadown.

column1: == History ==
=== Early history and Plantation of Ulster ===
The Portadown area had long been populated by Irish Gaels. At the beginning of the 1600s
column2: it lay within the district of Clancann (Clann Chana)
column3: which was part of the larger territory of Oneilland (Uí Nialláin). This district was named after the dominant local clan—the Mac Cana—who had been in the area since before the 13th century. The Mac Cana were then a vassal sept of the O'Neills (Uí Néill). On the eastern banks of the River Bann was the district of Clanbrasil (Clann Bhreasail).The town's name comes from the Irish Port a' Dúnáin (or
column4: more formally
column5: Port an Dúnáin)
column6: meaning the port or landing place of the small fort. This was likely a fort of the Mac Cana.From 1594 until 1603
column7: the O'Neills and an alliance of other clans fought in the Nine Years' War against the English conquest of Ireland. This ended in defeat for the Irish clans
column8: and much of their land was seized by the English. In 1608
column9: James I of England began the Plantation of Ulster – the organised colonisation of this land by settlers from Great Britain.

column2: as part of the Plantation
column3: the lands of Portadown were granted to William Powell. In 1611
column4: he sold his grant of land to Reverend Richard Rolleston
column5: who in turn sold it in two portions to Richard Cope and Michael Obins. Obins built a large Elizabethan-style mansion for himself and his family
column6: and a number of houses nearby for English tenants. This mansion was in the area of the present-day Woodside estate
column7: and today's People's Park was part of its grounds. The park is now bounded on either side by Obins Street and Castle Street
column8: both of which are references to "Obin's Castle". In 1631
column9: Obins was granted a licence for a "fair and market"
column10: which led to the building of the first bridge across the River Bann shortly thereafter.

column1: === Irish rebellion of 1641 ===
During the Irish Rebellion of 1641
column2: Obins Castle was captured by a force of dispossessed Irish led by the Mac Cana
column3: the Magennises and the O'Neills. In one of the worst atrocities of the rebellion
column4: in November 1641
column5: Irish rebels forced about 100 captured English and Scottish settlers (or 'planters') off the Bann bridge and they either drowned or were shot. This became known as the "Portadown massacre"
column6: and partly precipitated the revenge attacks carried out in Ireland several years later by the forces of Oliver Cromwell. The Irish Confederate troops abandoned Obins Castle during the Cromwellian conquest of Ireland
column7: and Hamlet Obins (who had survived its capture) repossessed it in 1652. It was then passed to his son

column1: === World War II ===

A large prisoner-of-war (POW) camp was built at Portadown during World War II. It was at the site of a former sports facility on what was then the western edge of town. This area is now covered by housing from Fitzroy Street and the Brownstown Estates. The camp housed (mostly) German POWs. For a time these POWs were guarded by Welsh servicemen who had been transferred from Germany (known as "Bluecaps") and who were billeted at St Patrick's Hall in Thomas Street. Many of the Welsh soldiers chose to be demobilised to Portadown as they had formed relationships there.
The local newspaper carried a story of another POW camp
column2: adjacent to Killicomaine Castle (also known as Irwin's Castle) in what was then known as "Cullen's Lane" but is now called "Princess Way" and part of the Killicomaine estate
column3: built in 1954 and largely contemporary with other estates built by the then Portadown Borough Council and the former Northern Ireland Housing Trust (now called the Northern Ireland Housing Executive).In 2005
column4: a public air-raid shelter was uncovered during excavation works near the riverbank just outside the town centre. One of ten built by the council during World War II
column5: it is one of only two now remaining
column6: the other at the new roundabout on the Gilford Road
column7: and a rare example of public air raid shelters in Northern Ireland.

column1: === The Troubles ===
During the Troubles
column2: there were numerous shootings
column3: bombings and riots in Portadown. The conflict led to the deaths of 45 people in the town. Loyalists killed 25 people: 18 Catholic civilians
column4: three Protestant civilians
column5: two members of the security forces
column6: a republican paramilitary and a loyalist paramilitary. Irish republicans killed 18 people: nine members of the security forces
column8: seven Protestant civilians and one Catholic civilian. The security forces killed one Protestant civilian
column9: and another loyalist was killed by his own bomb. In 1993 and 1998
column10: the town centre was devastated by two large car bombs planted by republicans.

column1: The Troubles led to the town becoming segregated – the northwestern part of the town became almost wholly Catholic/Irish nationalist
column2: while the rest of the town became almost wholly Protestant/unionist. Portadown's 'Catholic district' is bordered by the railway line and by a security barrier ("peace wall") along Corcrain Road.The Troubles also intensified the long-running Drumcree marching dispute
column3: over Orange marches through the Catholic part of town. Each July from 1995 to 2000
column4: the dispute drew worldwide attention as it sparked protests and violence throughout Northern Ireland
column5: prompted a massive police/British Army operation
column6: and threatened to derail the peace process. The Army sealed-off the Catholic part of Portadown with large steel
column7: concrete and barbed-wire barricades and the situation was likened to a "war zone" and a "siege".Each summer
column9: there are many Protestant/loyalist marches in the town. Loyalists put up numerous flags and raise arches over some streets. These marches
column10: and the raising of these flags and arches near the homes of Catholic families
column11: continues to be a source of tension and sometimes violence.Community leaders in Portadown have been involved with the Ulster Project since it began in 1975. The project involves teenagers from both of Northern Ireland's main communities. The goal is to foster goodwill and friendship between them. Each year
column12: a group of teenagers are chosen to travel to the United States
column13: where they stay with an American family for a few weeks.

column1: == Geography ==
Portadown sits in a relatively flat part of Ireland
column2: near the southern shore of Lough Neagh. There are two small wetland areas on the outskirts of the town; one at Selshion in the west and another at Annagh in the south. The Ballybay River flows into the town from the west before joining the River Bann.

column1: === The River Bann ===
Most of the town is built on the western side of the River Bann
column2: and owes much of its prosperity to the river. It was the construction of the Newry Canal (linking Carlingford Lough with Lough Neagh) in 1740
column3: coupled with the growth of the railway in the 19th century
column4: which put Portadown at the hub of transport routes.

column1: There are three bridges across the river at Portadown. Bridge Street and Northway are both road bridges and there is a railway bridge beside the Northway. The 'Bann Bridge' on Bridge Street is the oldest. The story of this bridge is unusual in that it was built without a river running underneath it. After building was complete
column2: the course of the River Bann was diverted by some 100 yards to straighten a meander. The old riverbed was then built upon. An archaeological dig in the area of the old riverbed uncovered the bones of some of those drowned in the 1641 massacre. The current bridge has been widened twice since it was built.

=== Climate ===
The climate of Portadown is like that of much of the rest of the UK and Ireland
column2: being a temperate oceanic climate. It has mild temperatures throughout the year
column3: with summer temperatures not reaching levels to be deemed very hot and winter not very cold. Summer temperatures can reach more than 20 °C (68 °F) though it is rare for them to go higher than 30 °C (86 °F). The consistently humid climate that prevails over Ireland can make these temperatures feel uncomfortable when they stray into the high 20s °C (80–85 °F)
column4: more so than similar temperatures in hotter climates in the rest of Europe. It also receives a steady amount of rainfall throughout the year.

column1: == Governance ==

Portadown is part of the Upper Bann constituency for elections to the Northern Ireland Assembly and Parliament of the United Kingdom. The boundaries of the Assembly constituency and Parliament constituency are identical. This has long been a safe unionist seat.Portadown came under the governance of Portadown Borough Council following the Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898. This was abolished with the Local Government (Boundaries) Act (Northern Ireland) 1971 and the Local Government Act (Northern Ireland) 1972. Henceforth
column2: the town had been under the jurisdiction of the larger Craigavon Borough Council. However
column3: after local government reform the town is now part of one of Northern Ireland's largest councils
column4: the Armagh
column5: Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council. Councillors are elected to the council every four years by proportional representation.

column1: == Transport ==
A combination of road
column2: canal and rail links
column3: all converging on Portadown railway station
column4: gave it the nickname "Hub of the North" and this created employment through mass industry as well as helping the traditional agronomy of the area. The Newry Canal
column5: opened in 1742
column6: linked Carlingford Lough and the Irish Sea with Lough Neagh. It joined the River Bann a couple of miles to the southeast of Portadown. The canal opened up waterborne trade and left Portadown ideally situated to take full advantage of the trading routes. However
column7: the canal went into decline with the growth of the railway network and it closed to commercial traffic in the 1930s.

column1: With the establishment of the Great Northern Railway the overland trading routes were extended and delivery times shortened. The town's first railway station opened in 1842 in Edenderry.At Portadown railway station the line went in four directions – one went northeast toward Belfast
column2: one northwest toward Dungannon
column3: one southwest to Armagh and one southeast toward Newry and onward to Dublin. Today only the Belfast–Dublin line remains. Repair yards were opened in 1925 and these large concrete buildings dominated the skyline on the west of the town centre. In 1970 the current station  opened
column4: however this has recently saw mass renovation and refurbishment. This new station was complete in late 2012. The old Edenderry station
column5: on the other side of the river
column6: was demolished. The Northway bypass road opened around this time
column7: linking Portadown more directly with the "new town" of Craigavon. This meant building a new road bridge across the river. The road runs parallel with the railway line for most of its length.

column1: == Healthcare ==
Access to a GP is provided at Portadown Health Centre.  Hospital care and Accident and Emergency services are available at Craigavon Area Hospital
column2: built 1972 on the outskirts of town as part of the Craigavon development. This replaced Lurgan Hospital and the Carleton Maternity Hospital in Church Street as the primary source of care for the town. It serves approximately 241
column3: 000 people from Mid Ulster and is one of the main cancer treatment centres outside Belfast.

column1: == Media ==
Portadown's main local newspaper is the Portadown Times
column2: which is published by Johnston Publishing (NI). Although the newspaper focuses on the Portadown area
column3: it also serves towns and villages across north Armagh. It was founded in 1924 and is issued weekly. Until recently it was situated in the town centre at Church Street
column4: but has moved three miles out of town to Carn Industrial Estate.
